children.value: This is the first project of Wes Bos's

.
We will be building a "drumkit" as shown in the first two minutes of the video below. The page plays certain sound effects on pressing keys from A to L on the qwerty keyboard.

.embed-container { position: relative; padding-bottom: 56.25%; height: 0; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; } .embed-container iframe, .embed-container object, .embed-container embed { position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; }
Here is a codepen with the starter files (I have made
modifications to the pens since it's not running on the local filesystem) :
See the Pen JS30-01-DrumKit-a by Deepak Karki (@deepakkarki) on CodePen.
Let's have a look at the HTML content. The structure is rather simple - the main content is in the
tag which contains the all the
element displays the letter and corresponding sound beat. The key get's animated when the corresponding key is pressed on the keyboard. The

tag is essentially a span which is supposed to signify "user input from a keyboard, voice input, or any other text entry device", it's more to do with semantics than anything else! You can read more about it on the
tags, these contain the links to the audio files that are to be played on the correct key presses.

The HTML <audio> element is used to embed sound content in documents. It may contain one or more audio sources, represented using the src attribute or the <source> element: the browser will choose the most suitable one. It can also be the destination for streamed media, using a MediaStream. The `<audio>` tag does not render unless there is a `controls` attribute present.
properties you see are custom attributes which you can add to HTML elements. The general format is
. This allows us to associate custom data to HTML elements (without colliding with standard attributes) in a way it can be accessed by CSS selectors and programmatically via javascript.

HTML5 is designed with extensibility in mind for data that should be associated with a particular element but need not have any defined meaning. data-* attributes allow us to store extra information on standard, semantic HTML elements without other hacks such as non-standard attributes, extra properties on DOM, or Node.setUserData().
The CSS is pretty straightforward, here are the interesting bits
These main properties involved with the animation - the
class that does the transform. More about this later.
So this is what comes with the template, we have to write the javascript bits to get to the finished webpage.
We can brake the problem into three parts -
Capture the keystrokes - only letters from 'A' to 'L' on the qwerty keyboard, ignore the rest.
Play the corresponding sound on a valid keypress.
element that corresponds to the letter pressed.
We can capture keystrokes by adding a
event listener to the window object.
The event object has a keycode integer, which is the ascii value of the key pressed. This is where the
property becomes useful, we can select the elements based on keycode.
// selects the audio element where data-key="e.keyCode"
//if there is no audio element with the corresponding keyCode, then don't do anything
//else reset the audio time and play it
element gives us an object of type
which has access to the properties of
elements, as well as methods to manipulate them.
plays the audio file associated with the tag.
resets the audio time if it's already running, otherwise if you hold down a button, the audio wouldn't be played repeatedly because an previous instance is already playing.
Learn more about the audio tag @

The animation is done via CSS transitions. In the JS code we just add and remove the class
// will go in the playSound() function
If we recall, the transitions take
seconds. We want to remove the class
right after the animation completes. Rather than hardcoding it as
seconds in the code, we can just listen on the
event to be triggered on the element. Let's create a function
to take care of this logic.
//transitionend is triggered on a variety of properties, (border, box shadow, etc)
